student_essay:
To be honest, I had to watch The Perfect Secret not once, but twice. The first time, I
was not interested in the movie and had to take a break for two days. I didn't really give it a
chance, but the second time around, I decided to take notes and really try and focus on the
characters, and wow, did I make a mistake the first time! I fell in love with Bianca; from the
moment she talked to Pepe out on the patio about how to know if you are in love. She had
such an open mind and was such a sweetheart. She was definitely too good for Simon in
my opinion. I thought it was very interesting how Eva wanted to play this game, I knew from
the start it was just to see if her husband had been cheating on her, but I don't think she
realized how big of a mess she would create. From Carlotta’s phone call with her friend
Mouse talking about her and Leo’s nonexistent sex life (Video 1 at 43 minutes and 05
seconds till Video 2 at 2 minutes and 29 seconds), all the way to Leo and Pepe switching
phones so Leo wouldn't get caught with his “companion”, as he calls her (Video 1 at 40
minutes and 11 seconds) , and Pepe having to announce to all his friends that he was gay.
(Video 3 in 2 minutes, 55 seconds). I think why almost every culture can relate to this movie
is because everyone has secrets that hide from friends, family, and loved ones. Pepe was
hiding a huge part of himself from his friends because of the fear that they wouldn't accept
him or even like him anymore, and for a moment he was right in feeling that way. All three
of his friends, Rocco, Leo, and Simon, used hurtful language, and really made Pepe feel
uncomfortable with whom he is as a gay person (Video 2 at 34 minutes and 18 seconds). I
am glad that, at the end, the three boys made it up to Pepe by beating up the man who has
been sending hateful messages to him and became friends again. I think in every culture
we need to be honest and communicate with our friends and loved ones to avoid chaos
and drama, and to support them and love them for who they are.
feedback:
Hi Kealani, 

I appreciate that you took the time to watch the film twice and engage deeply with the characters the second time around. 

You mentioned that "all three" friends were hurtful to Pepe, but this misses the nuance of the scene: Simon was the aggressor with homophobic comments, while Rocco was actually quite supportive and tried to de-escalate the situation.

Finally, try to maintain a more formal academic tone in future assignments and double-check your grammar (see the attached suggestions). 

Overall, good work!

question: The Perfect Secret is a German adaptation of an Italian film called Perfetti Sconosciuti. The Italian original has made history by being adapted into at least 18 different languages besides German (https://www.imdb.com/list/ls082389916/Links to an external site.), such as Arabic, French, Korean, Greek, Turkish, Chinese, etc. Why does the topic/theme seem to have such universal applicability, i.e. fit into so many different cultural contexts? Please cite a scene and situation in the film that you think is particularly true-for-all relationships, either romantic relationships or friendships. Indicate, using a time stamp, where in the film this comes up (e.g., Video 2 at 12 min 30 seconds).
student_essay:
This film covers a range of topics and themes such as homophobia, infidelity, and
the nature of friendship, and due to these topics it is adapted in more than 18 languages
across different cultures. The film shows how a group of friends sit at a dinner table and
explore their hidden secret. It shows how little the friends and romantic partners know
each other and how all their secrets are hidden in their phones. The film is able to be
adapted into multiple cultures because of its simplicity. The film was able to cover a
series of topics simply in the setting of friends at a dinner table playing a game. At the
core of the story is the idea that our smartphones hold our most private thoughts,
conversations, and secrets. Since smartphones are now an essential part of daily life
across the world, the fear of having one's digital life exposed is something audiences
from many cultural backgrounds can immediately relate to.
The topic also resonates universally because infidelity, trust, and secrecy are
fundamental issues in both romantic relationships and friendships. While different
cultures may have different cultural norms regarding privacy or relationships, nearly all
people understand the tension between wanting to be fully known and wanting to
protect a certain part of themselves. The dinner-table setting reinforces this universality
as sharing a meal with close friends, showing how intimate and realistic the situation is,
allowing the story to be easily adapted to different cultural contexts without losing its
impact.
There are multiple scenes that can be true for all relationships. For instance, at 42
minutes and 17 seconds, Carlotta gets a call from her childhood where she begins to
give advice on how to improve Carlotta's sex life with Leo. As a woman, this is relatively
relatable as I tell my girlfriends everything. In almost every friendship I've had with
another woman it is normal to open up about everything including more private things.
So, I believe this scene wonderfully demonstrates female friendships. Even after
Carlotta ends the conversation with her friend she doesn’t really show shame but rather
says “yes, surprise I talk to my best friend about our sex life” demonstrating the lack of
judgment and the deep trust that can exist in close friendships. This moment also shows
how different female relationships are in comparison to male friendships considering
Leo was very shocked by how comfortable she was to talk to her best friend about
private matters.
Another scene is at 29 minutes and 10 seconds of the second clip. Leo and Pepe
switched phones so Carlotta wouldn’t find out about Leo’s affair. However that soon
backfires because Pepe was hiding a secret about being homosexual. The scene erupts
into a huge misunderstanding where Carlotta believes her husband, Leo is gay.
However despite Pepe and Leo both knowing the truth of the situation, Leo refuses to
expose Pepe. This shows how deep the trust goes within their friendship. Leo’s
marriage was on the verge of collapsing but he refused to admit the truth only to defend
and protect his close friend. I believe it's fair to say that this scene can be shown across
all friendships, because in all friendships trust runs deep and it demonstrates how
friends have each other's backs no matter the situation.
Overall, the film “Perfect Secret” shows that simple settings can explore universal truths
about relationships. Through the dinner-table game and the revelations in scenes with
Carlotta and Leo, the film highlights trust, secrecy, and loyalty in both friendships and
romantic partnerships. These experiences are relatable across cultures, which is why
the story has been adapted into so many languages. The film demonstrates that,
despite cultural differences, the complexities of human relationships are truly universal.
feedback:
Hi Kseniya, great job analyzing the film's gender dynamics. Your point about Carlotta was excellent: the universality here is that female friendships often involve a level of disclosure that men find shocking. 

However, you need to be much more concise. You exceeded the maximum word count by a wide margin. You have two introductory paragraphs that say essentially the same thing. You could combine these into one. 

Additionally, please proofread for phrasing and punctuation. In terms of phrasing, for example, you wrote "Carlotta gets a call from her childhood...." You likely meant "from her childhood friend." For punctuation, watch your commas. "However that soon backfires..." needs a comma after "However."

student_essay:
The German movie The Perfect Secret shows a theme that seems to work in almost any culture, how honesty, trust, and privacy affect relationships. The movies main idea is that a group of friends decides to share all the messages on their phones during a dinner. This situation creates a lot of tension, surprises, and funny moments. I think this story can be told in so many different countries because almost everyone has a phone and uses it to talk to friends, family, or romantic partners. Everyone also has secrets or things they keep private, so the story feels familiar no matter where you live.

One scene that really shows this is around 12 minutes and 30 seconds into the movie, when the game starts and Bianca realizes how much personal information everyone can see. The friends all react with awkward laughter, shock, and a little panic. This scene shows how hard it is to balance honesty and privacy in relationships. It’s something everyone can relate to because we all have moments when we don’t want others to know everything about us, even our closest friends or partners. Another part that feels universal is when Pepe helps his student talk to a girl on social media. It shows that people often try to help each other but might do it in ways that reveal secrets or private things. These moments are both funny and real because they show how complicated relationships can be, even with good intentions.

Overall, I think The Perfect Secret works in so many cultures because it talks about things that are true for everyone trust, curiosity, and dealing with secrets. The story uses a smartphone, which everyone knows, but it’s really about how people interact, what they hide, and how they deal with each other. That’s why the movie has been adapted into so many languages and still makes sense everywhere.
feedback:
Hi Ciara,

You correctly identified the film's central themes of trust and privacy.

However, you claimed that the game starts around 12:30, but at that point in the film, the characters are simply having a conversation about Pepe's new partner; the game has not begun.

Additionally, phrases like "awkward laughter, shock, and a little panic" and "funny moments" are a bit general. To improve, you need to analyze why the character behaves as they do. Lastly, be careful with punctuation errors and possessive apostrophes.

Overall, good work!

In fact, as can be seen in the suicide/death of one of the characters, drinking can also enhance negative and depressive feelings. However, although drinking was not the solution, and the film does not have a traditional Hollywood-like happy end, the main character, Martin, did undergo a transformation.

student_essay:
At first glance, Another Round is a fascinating film. You begin watching it, thinking, "Is there anything positive I will learn from this film?" But as the film goes on, it becomes clear that the central message of the film, being in a constant but controlled stupor will benefit your life, is not sustainable. This message is conveyed mainly through Martin's transformation, which begins as personal and emotional stagnation and culminates in a completely new outlook on life.  

Early in the film, Martin seemed depressed but also detached from his career and family. Around 5:00 minutes, he struggles to lead his class through a lesson on Winston Churchill and appears mentally dissociated from both the material and his students. In fact, his lack of focus becomes so apparent that students begin correcting him on the lesson's historical details, most notably Malthe. This emotional detachment continues at home, where, at approximately 5:55, the film cuts to a solemn Martin. Although he is physically present at the table, you can tell Martin has completely given up on life. He barely engages in conversation with his wife or kids and appears emotionally distant. This scene establishes that Martin's depression is affecting all areas of his life.

A strong contrast happens later in the movie during the early stages of the alcohol experiment. Before entering his classroom, Martin tests his BAC (blood alcohol content) and reveals he is at a .047. Reflecting on what his group discussed, he is eager to see the effects. The camera then opens up to the classroom at around 1:03 in the second video, with Martin's demeanor toward his students changed. In the scene, Martin is much more relaxed, engaging with his students, and confident! He explains the lesson using an effective election metaphor, which gets many more students involved in the material.

The insight that allows Martin to grow is the realization that alcohol was never the true source of his confidence or his happiness. While the drinking lowered his anxiety and allowed him to reconnect to teaching, it created a nasty product in the end. The experiment revealed that all the qualities Martin thought he had lost were still inside him this whole time. By the end of the film, Martin realizes that real growth happens when you're actively engaged in life rather than escaping from it.
feedback:
Hi Daniel, 

This is a fantastic essay. You did a great job identifying Martin's initial state not just as "sad," but as "mentally disassociated" and "detached." Also, your conclusion is a perfect summary of the film's existential theme. 

Excellent work.

Shortly after, Anika leaves the table saying she can no longer love him or be with him. On the
